snippet: The close ties resulted in public officials doing car companies’ bidding, sometimes to the detriment of environmental standards, environmentalists and others say.
abstract: Environmentalists and other critics argue German government's close ties to auto industry are partly to blame for Volkswagen's emissions-testing scandal; politicians look to distance themselves amid suggestions Chancellor Angela Merkel and others failed to enforce high standards and manipulated European leaders in industry's favor.

byline.contributor: Graham Bowley contributed reporting from Brussels, and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: The close ties resulted in public officials doing car companies’ bidding, sometimes to the detriment of environmental standards, environmentalists and others say.

headline.main: In Germany, a Cozy Relationship Between Carmakers and Government
headline.print_headline: Critics Link German Scandal to Government’s Close Ties With Industry
